p: Piper caninum. An EO, according to da Silva et al. [ 32], was characterized mainly by safrole (25.5%), similar to P. auritum (leaf EO, 70%), Piper callosum (leaf EO, 70%), P. hispidinervum (leaf EO, 81–88%), P. betle (floral EO, 27.6%), Piper mikanianum (leaf EO, 82%) and Piper xylosteoides (aerial parts EO 47.83%). The other main compounds were β-caryophyllene (9.8%), germacrene D (7.8%), β-pinene (4.9%), δ-elemene (4.1%), linalool (2.9%), limonene (2.7%), eugenol (2.4%), τ-muurolol (2.4%), bicyclogermacrene (2.3%), camphor (0.3%), α-cubebene (0.5%), β-cubebene (0.3%), aromadendrene (0.8%), allo-aromadendrene (0.3%), α-bisabolene (0.4%), germacrene B (1.1%), globulol (0.3%), α-cadinol (1.0%) and farnesyl acetate (1.2%) [ 32].
